name: Mesopotamian Spiny-tailed Lizard
description: A robust lizard with a large head, strong legs, and a wide body. Its tail is covered with scales that protrude into short spines.
spread_note: From eastern Iraq through Iran to Kuwait
proportions: Length up to 50 cm; weight over 1 kg
reproduction: Females lay 10–40 eggs; incubation lasts 70–80 days.
attractions: Rare both in the wild and in captivity, little is known about its life. Like other spiny-tailed lizards, it is active during the day and enjoys basking. It becomes lighter in color in the sun and darkens in the cold, as dark coloration better absorbs heat, warming it faster. It lives in colonies and spends nights in burrows it digs itself.
breeding: The first three Mesopotamian spiny-tailed lizards arrived at the zoo in 2012; the first successful breeding occurred in 2014.
